annotations:
[('Just to make this dock my home', [['Otis Redding, while touring with his band members, began to weary from all the traveling they had done. When seeing three large letters   “LSD” in the windows of his band practice room, he decided they would stay there. He wrote this song on a houseboat which they rented behind the Marin County heliport (where the windows were) in Sausalito.

http://www.marinscope.com/sausalito_marin_scope/opinion/sausalito-historical-society-sittin-at-which-dock-of-the-bay/article_9ae6cf2a-3f5f-57bb-b57e-0709d4e4b994.html']]), ('Everything still remains the same', [['The problems he had back home are the same as  the ones he has now.

The feelings here are right in line with this verse from Jackson Brownes' “Your Bright Baby Blues”:

Well, I’ve been up and down this highway
Far as my eyes can see
No matter how fast I run
I can never seem to get away from me"']]), ('Look like nothing’s gonna change', [['It’s here in the song, he reveals his true mood as he realizes it’s not all as good as he thought it would be.']]), ('Watching the tide roll away', [['All his troubles and obligations (and as it turns out, all his aspirations) are gone away. All he does now is watch the tide roll in and out.']]), ('Sittin’ here resting my bones
 And this loneliness won’t leave me alone', [['At first glance, this line seems to reference the death of Redding’s bandmates.  It’s more likely it’s a phrase used to cement the emotion in the song: he’s moved across the country to a new environment and to start a new life, but he himself hasn’t changed.

Redding recorded this song on 6 December 1967. It hit No. 1 on the pop and R&B charts the following year, but Redding and his band mates died in a plane crash  in Wisconsin on 10 December 1967.']]), ('Now, I’m just gonna sit at the dock of the bay', [['Otis was staying at a boathouse (in Sausalito, across the bay from San Francisco), which is where he got the idea of the ship coming in.']]), ('’Cause I’ve had nothing to live for
 And look like nothin’s gonna come my way', [['Ending up in the ‘Frisco Bay was not a goal for Redding. Rather than show California as this warm sunny place; Redding reveals this place does not mean much to him.']]), ('I’m sittin’ on the dock of the bay', [['When the song was first recorded, producers worried that the sound would be too pop for Redding. They made plans to have a gospel act sing in the background of the song, but that never ended up happening.']]), ('So I’m just gonna sit on the dock of the bay
 Watching the tide roll away', [['Guitarist Steve Cropper said in a interview in 1990 about Redding that: “Otis was one of those kind of guys who had 100 ideas. Anytime he came in to record, he always had 10 or 15 different intros or titles, or whatever. He had been at San Francisco playing The Fillmore, and he was staying at a boathouse, which is where he got the idea of the ship coming in. That’s about all he had: "I watch the ships come in and I watch them roll away again.” I took that and finished the lyrics. If you listen to the songs I wrote with Otis, most of the lyrics are about him. He didn’t usually write about himself, but I did."

Cropper wrote most of the song himself, going off an idea that Redding had.']]), ('I left my home in Georgia
 Headed for the ’Frisco bay', [["At the time Otis conceptualized the song he was living in San Francisco. Born in Dawson, GA and raised in Macon, Ga, he grew up with the music of Sam Cooke and Little Richard.

More generally, “(Sittin' On) the Dock of the Bay” was written in 1967, and thus acknowledges the shift of gravity in American music to the west coast with the incipient hippie movement."]])]

annotations:
[('Strumming my pain with his fingers
 Singing my life with his words
 Killing me softly with his song', [['According to songwriter Lori Lieberman, Killing Me Softly with His Song was inspired by Don McLean, whom she was watching in concert.

McLean was performing his song Empty Chairs at the Troubadour Night Club, when 20 year old Lori began writing notes on a napkin about how the song made her feel.

She called up fellow songwriter Norman Gimbel, reading her thoughts to him, driving him to take an existing song title and her thoughts and write these lyrics.



Lori and Norman in 1974, when they were lovers.']])]

name: She's Always a Woman
lyrics:
[Verse 1]
She can kill with a smile
She can wound with her eyes
She can ruin your faith with her casual lies
And she only reveals
What she wants you to see
She hides like a child
But she's always a woman to me

[Verse 2]
She can lead you to love
She can take you or leave you
She can ask for the truth
But she'll never believe you
And she'll take what you give her
As long as it's free
Yeah, she steals like a thief
But she's always a woman to me

[Chorus]
Oh, she takes care of herself
She can wait if she wants
She's ahead of her time
Oh, and she never gives out
And she never gives in
She just changes her mind
[Verse 3]
And she'll promise you more
Than the Garden of Eden
Then she'll carelessly cut you
And laugh while you're bleedin'
But she'll bring out the best
And the worst you can be
Blame it all on yourself
Cause she's always a woman to me

[Chorus]
Oh, she takes care of herself
She can wait if she wants
She's ahead of her time
Oh, and she never gives out
And she never gives in
She just changes her mind

[Verse 4]
She is frequently kind
And she's suddenly cruel
She can do as she pleases
She's nobody's fool
But she can't be convicted
She's earned her degree
And the most she will do
Is throw shadows at you
But she's always a woman to me
[Outro]
Mmm
Mmm
annotations:
[('She is frequently kind
 And she’s suddenly cruel', [['This woman can turn on a dime which can be good or bad depending on the time of the day.']]), ('But she can’t be convicted
 She’s earned her degree', [['What ever she might have done it can not change the fact that she has proved herself with her intellect.']]), ('She’s ahead of her time', [['This woman doesn’t need to look for fashion, or follow cultural oppression, because she’s already ahead, she dictates what happens in the future, she is clearly unique to the time period.']]), ('She can lead you to love
 She can take you or leave you', [['The woman Billy is talking about is clearly the one who dictates what happens, she leads you on and decides what will happen. Kind of like a purgatory situation, the tangible factor being whether she likes you enough.']]), ('But she’ll bring out the best
 And the worst you can be
 Blame it all on yourself
 Cause she’s always a woman to me', [['Her best attribute is to bring out the best qualities in a person (which can help you in life) and the worse ones (which can hinder you). But it isn’t her fault for doing so, she’s just being herself among friends and loved ones.']]), ('Oh, she takes care of herself
 She can wait if she wants', [['She’s probably got her own house, her own car, a great job; she knows how to work hard and doesn’t need a man financially or emotionally, so she’s not gonna come chasing after anyone.

Another way to interpret this is a fancy play-on-words. She can wait because she’s ahead of her time, meaning she’s matured so much already that she can wait for the rest of the world to mature enough to her level.']]), ('She can ask for the truth
 But she’ll never believe you', [['She already has made up her mind but she just wants to know if you’ll tell her what she wants to hear. Even if you do, she may think you’re lying. This kind of mindset is emotionally distancing, but will drive a guy crazy over trying to get closer to her, like an emotional tug-of-war.']]), ('She can kill with a smile
 She can wound with her eyes
 She can ruin your faith with her casual lies
 And she only reveals
 What she wants you to see', [['She’s really hot, enough to drive a guy nuts just by giving him one of those looks. She’s also mysterious, which makes her even more enticing and sexy.']]), ('She can do as she pleases
 She’s nobody’s fool', [['She’s got a take charge, wear-the-pants kind of personality. The kind of woman Sandra Bullock has played in movies like The Blind Side.']]), ('And she’ll promise you more
 Than the Garden of Eden
 Then she’ll carelessly cut you
 And laugh while you’re bleedin’', [['The Garden of Eden is a biblical reference from the book of Genesis where God made a beautiful garden for Adam and Eve, now a common poetic metaphor for “perfection”.

This woman can be quite ruthless. She plays games with his mind, making all sorts of promises with no intention of fulfilling them, and then just laughs it off later. This can be reflective of Billy Joel’s then-wife Elizabeth Weber Small’s “tough-as-nails” negotiating style. His guitarist at the time called her…

A perfect representative for Billy; she was a cold-hearted, black and white woman.
- From the biography, I Go to Extremes: The Billy Joel Story

The way she acts carefree about all this probably makes it even harder to be mad at her. If she’s acting like nothing is wrong, and you want to be with her, then you ignore your frustration and play along.']])]

Only shadows ahead, barely clearing the roof
Get to know the feeling of liberation and release

[Chorus]
Hey now, hey now, don't dream it's over
Hey now, hey now, when the world comes in
They come, they come to build a wall between us
You know they won't win

[Outro]
Don't let them win
Hey now, hey now
Hey now, hey now
Hey now, hey now
Don't let them win
They come, they come
Don't let them win
Hey now, hey now (yeah)
Hey now,  hey now
annotations:
[('Only shadows ahead, barely clearing the roof
 Get to know the feeling of liberation and release', [['He wants her to release the weight of her baggage (shadows) off of her shoulders. He pleads that she finds freedom within herself.']]), ('In the paper today, tales of war and of waste
 But you turn right over to the TV page', [['Ignorance is bliss. He ignores the world’s efforts to keep his lover and himself apart; and, he chooses instead to focus on the beauty that remains.']]), ('But you’ll never see the end of the road
 While you’re traveling with me', [['In this line, the singer is guaranteeing that he will whole-heartedly remain in this relationship (the road), no matter what the obstacles that may lie ahead.']]), ('Hey now, hey now, don’t dream it’s over', [['Interesting ambiguity here. The singer could mean “don’t dream that it’s over”, i.e. we haven’t reached the end yet, there’s still a chance for us.

Or he could mean “don’t dream, because it’s over”, basically the opposite.

Given that one member of Crowded House said the song is “about not giving up hope”, the former, more optimistic interpretation seems more likely.']]), ('Try to catch a deluge in a paper cup', [['A metaphor for trying to deal with a big problem with wildly insufficient resources.']]), ('Now I’m towing my car, there’s a hole in the roof', [['A car is perfectly drive-able with a hole in its roof, though the hole still is a persistent problem.

Continuing this metaphor through the lense of a break-up, the author is staking that the relationship is perfectly fine to keep moving forward, alas, he has still had to “tow it away” due to the perceived problems with it.

Whether begrudgingly or passively, the author has accepted his partner’s wish to end the relationship despite the fact that it can still function in his eyes.']]), ('Now I’m walking again to the beat of a drum', [['This is probably reference to the famous advice from Henry David Thoreau:

If a man does not keep pace with his companions, perhaps it is because he hears a different drummer. Let him step to the music which he hears, however measured or far away.

In this case, the “different drummer” is his love for the subject of the song, ignoring “the world”, which does not want them to be together.']]), ('There is freedom within, there is freedom without', [['There is freedom within the relationship and there’s freedom without it. He is validating his and her view respectively. She doesn’t want to be with him any longer, but he wants to be with her.']])]

name: Fast Car
lyrics:
[Verse 1]
You got a fast car

Maybe we'll make something

[Verse 2]

You'll find work and I'll get promoted

Buy a bigger house and live in the suburbs

[Chorus]
So I remember when we were driving

City lights lay out before us
And your arms felt nice wrapped around my shoulder
And I-I had a feeling that I belonged
I-I had a feeling I could be someone, be someone, be someone
[Verse 5]
You got a fast car
I got a job that pays all our bills
You stay out drinkin' late at the bar
See more of your friends than you do your kids
I'd always hoped for better
Thought maybe together you and me'd find it
I got no plans, I ain't going nowhere
So take your fast car and keep on driving

[Chorus]
So remember when we were driving
Driving in your car
Speed so fast it felt like I was drunk
City lights lay out before us
And your arm felt nice wrapped around my shoulder
And I-I had a feeling that I belonged
I-I had a feeling I could be someone, be someone, be someone

[Refrain]
You got a fast car
Is it fast enough so you can fly away?
You gotta make a decision
Leave tonight or live and die this way
annotations:
[('I been working at the convenience store
 Managed to save just a little bit of money', [['Mentioning that she’s ‘starting from zero with nothing to lose’, the narrator is working a bottom-of-the-barrel type job at a convenience store. Not a hefty paycheck, but at least she is starting somewhere.']]), ('So I remember when we were driving
 Driving in your car
 Speed so fast it felt like I was drunk
 City lights lay out before us
 And your arms felt nice wrapped around my shoulder', [['She said it best, expressing the intoxicating effects of being with someone you love… She draws a parallel between speeding through a city and speeding through emotions.

In the car they’re still, yet the outside world is zipping by, similar to the stillness at the center of the racing heart in love. In both situations, senses can feel hyper-stimulated, yet simultaneously calm and at peace, relaxed.

Her delivery of these lyrics are what makes them so powerful, to me. Beautiful lyricism. Thanks for reading :)']]), ('Maybe together we can get somewhere
 Any place is better', [['“We should make a getaway from the clutches of poverty, and go anywhere else–I just want to be anywhere but in this situation.”']]), ('And I-I had a feeling that I belonged
 I-I had a feeling I could be someone, be someone, be someone', [['Tracy is reminiscing about a surreal experience she had while the unnamed owner of the car was driving her through the city, and for the first time she felt like she could do more with her life. This experience forms the basis of her desperation to escape which is present throughout the song.']]), ('See, my old man’s got a problem
 He lives with a bottle, that’s the way it is
 He says his body’s too old for working
 His body’s too young to look like his
 When momma went off and left him
 She wanted more from life than he could give
 I said “Somebody’s gotta take care of him”
 So I quit school, and that’s what I did', [['This verse tells the tragic story of how Tracy ended up in her current situation. After her mother left her alcoholic and unemployed father, Tracy was forced to give up her dreams and her education to take care of him. She has sacrificed everything for her deadbeat father, and now she is living with the consequences of it.

This sheds some light on why Tracy is so desperate to escape, and why she keeps talking about the fast car, hoping that she can “fly away” from her current life, leaving the past behind her and finally pursuing a proper life for herself.']]), ('You and I can both get jobs
 Finally see what it means to be living', [['Working in a convenience store has little to offer in the way of wages, and it would be highly unrealistic to make a proper living out of it. Tracy is hoping she can get a decent job in the city, and finally live a decent life.']]), ('And I-I had a feeling that I belonged
 I-I had a feeling I could be someone, be someone, be someone', [['The phrase “a feeling” takes on a darker meaning in this chorus. In the earlier choruses, it reflected the narrator’s optimism that things will get better, and that someday she would “be someone.” However, now that she’s given up on her optimism, she realises that that feeling of belonging and being someone was never any more than a feeling.']]), ('I got no plans, I ain’t going nowhere', [['The first two verses and the previous verse all talk about the narrator’s plans for the future- to move to the city in the first two verses and to escape poverty in the previous verse. This line could suggest that the narrator has given up on dreaming.

The alternate and more optimistic interpretation is that the narrator is has decided not to compromise anymore, and has now decided that she should kick out her partner, who can’t be committed to her or their family. She’s cutting loose the dead weight that she thought was her ideal partner, as he has proven himself to be useless. She is covering all the bills. She is taking care of the kids. He and his fast car and his drinking can get the hell out. The chorus after these lines is about making her partner consider what he really wants in life. If he just wants to party and drive fast, she has no room for him in the life she has built for her kids and herself.']]), ('Is it fast enough so you can fly away?', [['She’s almost threatening her partner? Like, he better get out of her life quick with his fancy little fast car or she’ll give him hell.
Distinctive transition/contrast from her attitude before from “we” to “you”, suggesting she’s realised the one thing holding her down in her new life and she’s dropping it, leaving her partner to fend for himself.']]), ('So take your fast car and keep on driving', [['She’s sick of her partner’s indifference and lack of contribution to their state of living so she’s being assertive and kicking them out. It seems their ‘fast car’ made them attractive in that they were the perfect getaway, and now the ‘fast car’ is the only dreamy/happy/utopian (might need different words there) aspect they hold onto while the rest of their life falls apart. At this point, the fast car is being shunned, contrasted to before, when it was idolised as her “ticket to anywhere”.']])]

 Tell me I’m safe, you’ve got me now', [['This friend or lover was there for Jess in the moments when it could have been over. She was in a dark place and in the hopelessness she must have felt, the source of hope came to her. Her savior tells her there that she’s okay and they’ve got her signifying they’ll always be there for her.']]), ('Came to you with a broken faith

This is a song about the need to have someone who cares when you are at your most vulnerable. name: Shallow
lyrics:
[Verse 1: Bradley Cooper]
Tell me somethin', girl
Are you happy in this modern world?
Or do you need more?
Is there somethin' else you're searchin' for?

[Refrain: Bradley Cooper]
I'm fallin'
In all the good times
I find myself longing for change
And, in the bad times, I fear myself

[Verse 2: Lady Gaga]
Tell me something, boy
Aren't you tired tryna fill that void?
Or do you need more?
Ain't it hard keepin' it so hardcore?

[Refrain: Lady Gaga]
I'm falling
In all the good times
I find myself longing for change
And, in the bad times, I fear myself

[Chorus: Lady Gaga]
I'm off the deep end, watch as I dive in
I'll never meet the ground
Crash through the surface where they can't hurt us
We're far from the shallow now
[Post-Chorus: Lady Gaga & Bradley Cooper]
In the sha-ha, sha-hallow
In the sha-ha, sha-la-la-la-low
In the sha-ha, sha-hallow
We're far from the shallow now

[Bridge: Lady Gaga]
Oh, ha, ah, ha
Oh-ah, ha

[Chorus: Lady Gaga]
I'm off the deep end, watch as I dive in
I'll never meet the ground
Crash through the surface where they can't hurt us
We're far from the shallow now

[Post-Chorus: Lady Gaga & Bradley Cooper]
In the sha-ha, shallow
In the sha-ha, sha-la-la-la-low
In the sha-ha, shallow
We're far from the shallow now
annotations:
[('I’m off the deep end, watch as I dive in
 I’ll never meet the ground
 Crash through the surface where they can’t hurt us
 We’re far from the shallow now', [['These lines were written by Ally before her breakthrough. She alludes to her relationship with Jackson but mostly her dream of becoming an artist.  She’ll “never meet the ground” because of the high she experiences while seeing her dreams come true.

To “go off the deep end” means to lose control or go crazy, possibly out of anger. Ally wants to be judged for her voice, her talent, and her message, not her looks.

Jackson loves Ally for who she is, rather than her looks, which explains the line, “We’re far from shallow now.” The night that Ally and Jackson first meet, she explains to him that her looks, especially her nose, have kept her from success:

Ally: Almost every single person has told me they liked the way I sounded but they didn’t like the way I look.
Jackson: I think you’re beautiful.

“Far from shallow” also highlights how Ally’s music tends to be meaningful. In the second half of the film, her manager, Rez, convinces her to begin performing simple pop songs, which Jackson considers mindless and “shallow.”']]), ('Tell me something, boy
 Aren’t you tired tryna fill that void?
 Or do you need more?
 Ain’t it hard keepin’ it so hardcore?', [['Ally sees through Jackson’s “hardcore rock star” persona. He struggles with alcoholism, which he uses to try to “fill the void” left by his troublesome relationship with his late father and older brother.

Ally poses this question to Jackson on the very first night they meet. This makes Jackson vulnerable since Ally is able to quickly see the real person beneath the persona that he puts on for the public.']]), ('I’m fallin’
 In all the good times
 I find myself longing for change
 And, in the bad times, I fear myself', [['Jackson may be falling into his alcoholic tendencies and getting caught up in his rock star lifestyle. On the other hand, he could be falling in love with Ally. The mirrored narrative throughout the song shows that the characters help each other in different ways. Jackson helps Ally propel her career, while Ally helps Jackson with his internal battles.

The line goes on to give insight into Jackson’s thoughts – he is deeply unhappy such that even in the good times he longs for change and when times are tough he fears himself and what he could do (i.e. hurting himself or those around him)']]), ('Tell me somethin’, girl
 Are you happy in this modern world?
 Or do you need more?
 Is there somethin’ else you’re searchin’ for?', [['Cooper’s character, Jackson Maine, poses this question to Gaga’s character, Ally, at a key turning point in A Star is Born. Ally is a gifted songwriter employed at a restaurant, and she occasionally performs at a drag bar. Jackson questions whether she is happy being complacent, or whether she dreams of a life as a superstar. Jack is the catalyst on Ally’s singer/songwriter journey–he compels her to step out of her comfort zone and follow her dreams into superstardom.']])]

name: How Do I Live
lyrics:

How do I ever, ever survive?
How do I, how do I, oh, how do I live?

[Bridge]
Please, tell me, baby
How do I go on if you ever leave?
Baby, you would take away everything, I need you with me
Baby, don't you know that you're everything good in my life?
And tell me now

[Chorus]
How do I live without you? I want to know
How do I breathe without you if you ever go
How do I ever, ever survive?
How do I, how do I, oh, how do I live?
How do I live without you?
How do I live without you, baby?
How do I live?

name: Drops of Jupiter (Tell Me)
lyrics:
[Verse 1]
Now that she's back in the atmosphere
With drops of Jupiter in her hair
She acts like summer and walks like rain
Reminds me that there's a time to change, hey
Since the return of her stay on the moon
She listens like spring and she talks like June, hey
Hey, hey-yeah

[Chorus]
But tell me, did you sail across the sun?
Did you make it to the Milky Way
To see the lights all faded
And that heaven is overrated?
And tell me, did you fall from a shooting star?
One without a permanent scar
And did you miss me while you were
Looking for yourself out there?

[Verse 2]
Now that she's back from that soul vacation
Tracing her way through the constellation, hey, mmm
She checks out Mozart while she does Tae-Bo
Reminds me that there's room to grow, hey, yeah
Now that she's back in the atmosphere
I'm afraid that she might think of me as
Plain ol' Jane told a story about a man
Who was too afraid to fly so he never did land
[Chorus]
But tell me, did the wind sweep you off your feet?
Did you finally get the chance
To dance along the light of day
And head back to the Milky Way?
And tell me, did Venus blow your mind?
Was it everything you wanted to find?
And did you miss me while you were
Looking for yourself out there?

[Bridge]
Can you imagine no love, pride, deep-fried chicken
Your best friend always sticking up for you
Even when I know you're wrong?
Can you imagine no first dance, freeze-dried romance
Five-hour phone conversation
The best soy latte that you ever had, and me?

[Breakdown]
But tell me, did the wind sweep you off your feet? (Feet)
Did you finally get the chance
To dance along the light of day (Light of day)
And head back toward the Milky Way?
And tell me, did you sail across the sun?
Did you make it to the Milky Way
To see the lights all faded
And that heaven is overrated?
Tell me, did you fall from a shooting star?
One without a permanent scar
And did you miss me while you were
Looking for yourself?
[Outro]
Na, na, na, na, na, na
Na, na, na, na, na, na
And did you finally get the chance
To dance along the light of day?
Na, na, na, na, na, na
Na, na, na, na, na, na
And did you fall from a shooting star?
Fall from a shooting star?
Na, na, na, na, na, na
Na, na, na, na, na, na
And are you lonely looking for yourself out there?
annotations:
[('Now that she’s back from that soul vacation
 Tracing her way through the constellation, hey, mmm
 She checks out Mozart while she does Tae-Bo
 Reminds me that there’s room to grow, hey, yeah', [['Believing that his mother’s spirit has returned, he is beginning to find a new lease on life. So his mother’s ghost isn’t actually listening to Mozart and doing Tae-Bo (sorry to disappoint):



But she is inspiring him to lose his fears about trying new things (like Mozart and Tae-Bo of course) and to enjoy a full existence of fulfilling experiences. Even though his mother has died, it’s evident that he’s still learning valuable life lessons from her.']]), ('And are you lonely looking for yourself out there?', [['He knew she’d miss him too much to stay away forever…']]), ('Can you imagine no love, pride, deep-fried chicken
 Your best friend always sticking up for you
 Even when I know you’re wrong?
 Can you imagine no first dance, freeze-dried romance
 Five-hour phone conversation
 The best soy latte that you ever had, and me?', [['Glad that his mother’s spirit has returned to him, he asks her to imagine what things would be like if she’d stayed gone forever. He lists all of the great things she’d miss out on if she left for good, suggesting that while Heaven might have been spectacular beyond anyone’s wildest dreams, the two of them had found their own little piece of heaven in a life of simple pleasures. He wants her to know that even though she’s left the world, she’ll always be a part of his life.']]), ('Now that she’s back in the atmosphere
 I’m afraid that she might think of me as
 Plain ol’ Jane told a story about a man
 Who was too afraid to fly so he never did land', [['Since his mother has witnessed the magnificence of Heaven and has been presumably transformed by its amazing sights, he’s afraid that now that she’s returned to him in spirit, she’ll find that he’s experienced little to no personal growth, trapped in a boring and monotonous existence by his fear of the world and its never-ending changes.



How can he expect to look back proudly on his life when he never had the courage to actually live in the first place? It’s as though his mother has come back to remind him to live life to the fullest.']]), ('And tell me, did you fall from a shooting star?
 One without a permanent scar', [['Pat has a permanent scar on his chin, apparently the result of a car accident he was in when he was seventeen.



He brings this up as a way to ask his mother if she temporarily forgot about him while enjoying the grandeur of the heavens.']]), ('But tell me, did you sail across the sun?
 Did you make it to the Milky Way', [['Continuing the metaphorical comparison of his mother’s death to a trip into the sky, he asks her what she saw while in Heaven and what her experience there was like.']]), ('She acts like summer and walks like rain
 Reminds me that there’s a time to change, hey
 Since the return of her stay on the moon
 She listens like spring and she talks like June, hey', [['Since his mother’s death, he feels that her spirit has returned and taken on several different forms. He can sense her in the air, the elements, and the change of the seasons. To him, she’s everywhere and everything.']]), ('Now that she’s back in the atmosphere
 With drops of Jupiter in her hair', [['Train’s lead singer, Pat Monahan, stated in an interview that he wrote this song after his mother passed away, as an expression of the idea that even though her life on earth was over, she returned to him in spirit. These lines are metaphorical in nature, likening his mother’s death to a temporary trip to the heavens, from which her spirit returned with a heavenly glow as evidence of where she’d been.



It’s also worth noting that the planet Jupiter’s rain is composed of diamonds, rather than water. The notion that “drops of Jupiter” are adamantine can be read as an expression of Pat’s respect and affection for his mother; that her spirit returned wearing a crown.']])]

(You're still the one)

The one that I belong to

(You're still the one)
You're still the one that I love
The only one I dream of
You're still the one I kiss goodnight
You're still the one

[Instrumental Break]

[Chorus]
(Yeah, you're still the one)
You're still the one I run to
The one that I belong to
You're still the one I want for life
(Ooh, you're still the one)
You're still the one that I love
The only one I dream of
You're still the one I kiss goodnight
[Outro]
I'm so glad we made it
Look how far we've come my baby
annotations:
[('[Intro]', [['Shania whispers this intro, delivering her thesis on lasting love with tender and intimate tones.  You almost don’t need to hear what she’s saying in order to understand the meaning!']]), ('I’m so glad we made it
 Look how far we’ve come my baby', [['Symetrical with the spoken word intro, here’s Shania’s capstone statement: she’s happy that they are still together, and she still marvels at how much they’ve overcome together.']]), ('Ain’t nothing better
 We beat the odds together
 I’m glad we didn’t listen
 Look at what we would be missing', [['For Shania, there’s nothing better than being with this guy. She wants to prove that everyone who doubts their relationship is wrong. She’s glad they persevered through the criticism – they would’ve missed out on a great love if they hadn’t.']]), ('(You’re still the one)
 You’re still the one I run to
 The one that I belong to
 You’re still the one I want for life
 (You’re still the one)
 You’re still the one that I love
 The only one I dream of
 You’re still the one I kiss goodnight', [['Even after all these years, he’s still the person she’s in love with, and the only partner she loves. She still goes to him when she’s upset, she still dreams of him, and she still kisses him goodnight every night because she still loves him. She also says that she wants to be with him for the rest of her life.']]), ('They said, “I bet they’ll never make it”
 But just look at us holding on
 We’re still together, still going strong', [['Other people doubted their love and thought they wouldn’t work out. Maybe because most people tend to be skeptics, even when it comes to love. But Shania and her partner have proved the skeptics wrong! They are still together and happily in love.']]), ('We mighta took the long way
 We knew we’d get there someday', [['Things weren’t perfect or easy, but they still loved each other through it all.  The truth is no one knows the “right way” to love someone else – we can all think of some bad things to do, and some good things to do, but the path is not labelled with signs. Shania and her lover took the long way, but honestly that’s the only way to do it!']]), ('Looks like we made it
 Look how far we’ve come my baby', [['“Looks like” the lovers say – because they’ve weathered some storms and feel they are in a safe and stable place, from which it’s OK to look back… they stayed together through the rough times and the good times, and they’ve come a long way together.']]), ('And after all this time
 You’re still the one I love', [['Though she fell in love with him a long time ago, she’s yet to loose track of those very same feelings she first felt for him. He is still the love of her life.']]), ('And the first time you touched me, I felt love', [['Here Shania elaborates on the feeling of love at first sight – she’s moved from the feeling of seeing her lover to the feeling of being touched by her lover. She’s detailing the multiple dimensions of experiencing love!']]), ('I saw love', [['She felt “love at first sight” when she met her man.']])]

 Nothing to prove', [['This line is similar to the first Chorus
